title: 113_hr2368
content: The Act may be cited as the "Grants for Renewable Energy Education for the Nation Act" or the "GREEN Act". It includes provisions for Clean Energy Curriculum Development Grants. The "GREEN Act" authorizes the Secretary of Education to award grants to eligible partnerships for developing programs focused on clean energy, renewable energy, energy efficiency, climate change mitigation, and adaptation. Consultation with the Secretaries of Labor and Energy is required before grant solicitation. Eligible partnerships must include at least one local educational agency eligible for funding under the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006. The Technical Education Act of 2006 allows for grants to eligible partnerships involving educational institutions, postsecondary institutions, and community representatives with relevant experience. Applications must detail partner roles and capacities to support the program. The Technical Education Act of 2006 allows grants for partnerships involving educational institutions, postsecondary institutions, and community representatives. Applications must detail partner roles, career areas to be developed, program components, target students, replicability, applied learning, and academic reinforcement. The program of study must incorporate academic learning, describe delivery methods, ensure accessibility for all students, address placement in nontraditional fields, and involve consultation with relevant organizations. The Secretary prioritizes applications using online learning to reach students outside the partnership, focusing on low-performing students and special populations. A peer review committee evaluates grant applications, including educators and industry experts in relevant fields. Grants awarded under this section shall be used for the development, implementation, and dissemination of programs of study in career areas related to clean energy, renewable energy, energy efficiency, climate change mitigation, and climate change adaptation. SEC. 3. RENEWABLE ENERGY FACILITIES GRANTS. The Secretary of Education can award grants to eligible entities for developing energy-efficient career and technical education facilities that promote renewable energy practices. Eligible entities include local education agencies, area career and technical education schools, education service agencies, and postsecondary institutions. Applicants must submit applications to the Secretary for consideration. The Secretary will convene a peer review process to evaluate grant applications for energy-efficient career and technical education facilities. The peer review committee will include administrators with experience in energy-efficient facilities and industry experts in renewable energy. Grants will be used for sustainability evaluations and stakeholder engagement. The grant recipients are required to convene stakeholders, initiate activities related to renewable energy practices, purchase energy-efficient equipment for educational purposes, measure effectiveness of facilities, and communicate lessons learned. The grant recipients are required to convene stakeholders, initiate activities related to renewable energy practices, purchase energy-efficient equipment for educational purposes, measure effectiveness of facilities, and communicate lessons learned, including sharing building upgrade lessons with other institutions. Authorization of $100,000,000 for Education Secretary for grant program under this Act.
